choices.B: In the SSL VPN user group configuration, change Name to CN=SSLVPN,CN=Users,DC=trainingAD,DC=training,DC=lab.
choices.D: In the SSL VPN user group configuration, change Type to Fortinet Single Sign-On (FSSO).
choices.A: In the SSL VPN user group configuration, set Group Name to CN=SSLVPN,CN=Users,DC=trainingAD,DC=training,DC=lab.
choices.C: In the SSL VPN user group configuration, set Group Name to CN=Domain Users,CN=Users,DC=trainingAD,DC=training,DC=lab.

choices.A: Configure split-tunneling in the vap configuration.
choices.B: Configure split-tunneling in the wtp-profile configuration.
choices.C: Disable the Block Intra-SSID Traffic (Intra-vap-privacy) setting on the SSID (VAP) profile.
choices.D: Configure the printer as a wireless client on the Corporate wireless network.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
split-tunnel has to be configured both on vap and wtp-profile, but in this case the correct answer is A since it already has been enabled in wtp-profile according to configuration

Selected Answer: A
A is correct as you need to enable split-tunelling on the vap SSID profile. This is also mentioned on page 323 of study guide
Answer B is correct . Split tunnel can be enable on the profile

comments.content: it already is enabled in wtp-profile, according to configuration above, so the correct answer is A where it still needs to be enabled

questions.question_text: Which EAP method requires the use of a digital certificate on both the server end and the client end?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
Correct answer are C & D.
A it's not correct because if the communication is down the FortiGate can't retrieve the switch information, and B it's not correct to, because both exhibit have the same mac-address.

comments.content:
https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortiswitch/7.4.2/fortilink-guide/173271/fortiswitch-network-access-control
To show known NAC devices with a known location that match a NAC policy:

diagnose switch-controller mac-device nac known

To show pending NAC devices with an unknown location that match a NAC policy:

diagnose switch-controller mac-device nac onboarding

--> so I think it is B and C as the cli output shows, that the MAC address is known as a NAC device
Study guide p. 229 - enable device detection

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
unsure, but we donÂ´t know if device detection is enabled on switch-controller and which OS the device is.
https://docs.fortinet.com/document/fortiswitch/7.0.8/devices-managed-by-fortios/801195/enabling-network-assisted-device-detection

Selected Answer: BC
A incorrect because user wont be able to connect to port2 and generate traffic unless it is an unmanaged switch.

Selected Answer: AB
Option A is also true because the FortiSwitch device status is shown as down, which means that the management communication between FortiGate and FortiSwitch is not working properly. This could prevent the NAC policy from being applied correctly. Option C is false because the device operating system detected by FortiGate is Linux, which matches the NAC policy.

choices.D: Device detection is not enabled on VLAN 4089.
choices.C: The device operating system detected by FortiGate is not Linux.
choices.B: The MAC address configured on the NAC policy is incorrect.
choices.A: Management communication between FortiGate and FortiSwitch is down.

questions.question_text:
Refer to the exhibit.
//IMG//

Examine the FortiManager configuration and FortiGate CLI output shown in the exhibit.
An administrator is testing the NAC feature. The test device is connected to a managed FortiSwitch device (S224EPTF19005867) on port2.
After applying the NAC policy on port2 and generating traffic on the test device, the test device is not matching the NAC policy; therefore, the test device remains in the onboarding VLAN.
Based on the information shown in the exhibit, which two scenarios are likely to cause this issue? (Choose two.)
